qas.question: What area of study did professor Mark Long have a degree in?
In which year did Long publish his study?
How were rebounds of minority enrollment explained in Long's report?

answers.text: increasing minority enrollment in high schools

qas.question: Who would supposedly be the beneficiaries of a class-based style affirmative action?
What percentage of the black population thought affirmative action should be abolished?
What area of study did professor Mark Long have a job in?
In which year did Long reject his study?

plausible_answers.text: increasing minority enrollment in high schools of those states

qas.question: How were rebounds of minority enrollment rejected in Long's report?
Who would supposedly be the beneficiaries of a not class-based style affirmative action?
What percentage of the black population thought affirmative action should not be abolished?

context: A study in <a1_0><b6_0>2007<b6_0/><a1_0/> by Mark Long, an <a0_0><b5_0>economics<b5_0/><a0_0/> professor at the University of Washington, demonstrated that the alternatives of affirmative action proved ineffective in restoring minority enrollment in public flagship universities in California, Texas, and Washington. More specifically, apparent rebounds of minority enrollment can be explained by <a2_0><b7_0>increasing minority enrollment in high schools<a2_0/> of those states<b7_0/>, and the beneficiaries of class-based (not race) affirmative action would be <a3_0><b8_0>white students<b8_0/><a3_0/>. At the same time, affirmative action itself is both morally and materially costly: 52 percent of white populace (compared to <a4_0><b9_0>14<b9_0/><a4_0/> percent of black) thought it should be abolished, implying white distaste of using racial identity, and full-file review is expected to cost the universities an additional $1.5 million to $2 million per year, excluding possible cost of litigation.
